PRESENTATION STONE FROM PALACE OF WESTMINSTER


    Mr Speaker: Honourable Members will recollect that at a ceremony held at the Palace of Westminster on the 15th day of December, 1955, the Secretary of State for the Colonies, the Right Honourable Alan Lennox-Boyd, on behalf of Her Majesty's Government, handed to our then Chief Minister, Mr David Marshall, a piece of stone salvaged from the damage inflicted on the Victoria Tower in the Palace of Westminster by air raids during the last war. The Chief Minister accepted the gift on behalf of the Government of Singapore and I duly received it from the Chief Minister on behalf of Members of this Assembly for its incorporation in the fabric of this building.

    That has now been done. The Stone lies embedded in the wall behind the entrance to the Strangers Gallery with the inscription : - 






"FROM THE FABRIC OF THE


VICTORIA TOWER OF THE


PALACE OF WESTMINSTER


PRESENTED BY


HER MAJESTY'S GOVERNMENT


TO


THE SINGAPORE GOVERNMENT


15TH DECEMBER, 1955."


Column: 2079



    In reporting the gift to this Assembly, the Chief Minister referred to it as a "symbolic gesture of friendship and unity between the two Assemblies of Westminster and Singapore in the traditions of the democratic process".

    I would say further that I would like to think of the Stone itself as a constant reminder of that tradition of free and orderly debate "garnered" over the centuries in Westminster, the pattern of which we have adopted and are in the process of adapting for our purposes here in our Assembly.

ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

DR BENHAM'S ECONOMIC SURVEY OF SINGAPORE


    1. Mr G. A. P. Sutherland asked the Chief Minister why the report of Dr F. C. Benham, the Economic Adviser to the Chief Minister, of a survey conducted by him of the economic position of Singapore during 1956 which was reviewed in the local press on 28th June, 1957, was not in the first instance presented to the Legislative Assembly.

    The Chief Minister (Mr Lim Yew Hock): Mr Speaker, Sir, the report referred to was made to the Chief Minister by his Economic Adviser. It attempts to estimate progress made in economic fields since 1954. It does not in any way contain any statement of policy. There is nothing in the Standing Orders of the Legislative Assembly requiring that such report should be presented to the Legislative Assembly before it can be made public. The report has since been printed and copies have been furnished to Members of the Legislative Assembly as a matter of courtesy.

BENEFIT TO SINGAPORE OF ATTENDING RECENT I.L.O.
CONFERENCES

Column: 2082

SINGAPORE IMPROVEMENT TRUST HOUSES INSPECTION OF
APPLICATIONS REGISTER

SHORTAGE OF WATER IN RURAL AREAS


    13. Mr Goh Tong Liang asked the Minister for Local Government, Lands and Housing whether he is aware that the people in rural areas have been and are suffering hardships from lack of water; and whether he will take steps to alleviate their hardships.

Column: 2087



    Inche Abdul Hamid: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am aware of the need for increasing the supply of water to people in the rural areas and my Ministry has taken and will continue to take steps to increase such supplies.

    Before the Coalition Government took office in April, 1955, there were all in all only 213 standpipes in the rural areas of Singapore. Today, the rural areas of Singapore have 347 standpipes - 134 more than when this Government took office. In addition, 39 more which have been approved by the Rural Board are in the process of being installed. In money terms in 1954 for example, less than $450,000 were allocated by the Rural Board for water supply. In 1956, the allocation is slightly more than $1 million - an increase of approximately 222 per cent over the 1954 figure. This year, the Rural Board intends to step up its expenditure in this direction to approximately $1,170,000. Both in money terms and in terms of the number of standpipes built, it can be seen that my Ministry acting through the Rural Board has greatly increased its efforts to meet the demand for water supply in the rural areas. In addition to what I have just said, the Rural Board also operates a scheme to supply water by wagons during dry periods to outlying villages where standpipes are not available. In 1956, the expenditure in this connection was approximately $58,000.

PROGRESS IN UNIFYING PASSENGER TRANSPORT SYSTEM


    15. Mr John Ede asked the Minister for Communications and Works with reference to paragraph 10 of the White Paper (Sessional Paper No. Cmd. 48 of 1956), what progress has been made in the implementation of the various stages of the Government's policy of unifying the passenger transport system; what stages remain to be carried out; and on what dates will they be completed.

    Mr Francis Thomas: Mr Speaker, Sir, the hon. Member will recall that in paragraph 8 of the White Paper, Government agreed with the principal conclusions of the Hawkins Commission which were summarised in Chapter 27 of the report. The first matter for decision was therefore whether preparations should be made for the direct establishment of public ownership by means of a specially constituted public authority or whether as an intermediate step the formation of a statutory limited liability company should be aimed at. On this, the following progress has been made. Enquiries have been made as to whether the necessary capital for the formation of a statutory limited liability company was likely to be forthcoming from an overseas company with experience of transport administration as was suggested in paragraph 234 of the report. It soon, however, became apparent that a satisfactory solution was unlikely from such a source. Mr Hawkins himself then held a series of personal and informal discussions with members of the Chinese Bus Owners' Association. These members at one time showed considerable

Column: 2089

interest in the idea of amalgamation into a single company but the present indications are that the Chinese bus owners are not yet prepared to amalgamate into a single company. They have, however, undertaken to prepare and submit to me a memorandum containing alternative proposals for amalgamation. I understand that this memorandum can be expected at any time. The proposals will be carefully examined and the Government will then decide whether the alternative of a statutory limited liability company must be abandoned and, if so, the pace at which unification through a public authority should be pursued. This decision will be taken in the very near future and it would be made in the light of the demands made by other important development projects on the funds likely to be available in the next few years.

    The stages which remain to be carried out will, of course, depend on the decision to which I have just referred. They will vary according to the choice made. I do not think at this stage I can give any very useful information about them but I can, however, say that in the event of the decision being taken to establish a public authority, the first step will be the acquisition of the Singapore Traction company and we have commissioned accountants, with the concurrence of the company, to examine the records of the company and to submit a report which will form the basis of any subsequent negotiations for acquisition. The accountants have been pressed to complete this report as soon as possible. I am waiting to hear from them when the report may be expected. We have also anticipated the event by making a first draft of the legislation which will be required for the purposes of establishing a public authority. In the meantime, the statement in paragraph 10 of the White Paper (that the assumption by a unified undertaking of responsibility for operating any bus services in Singapore will not be possible before the middle of 1958) still stands.

ARCHITECTS (AMENDMENT) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

10.32 a.m.

    The Minister for Communications and Works (Mr Francis Thomas): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    Sir, hon. Members will recollect that in June of last year, they gave their unanimous approval to the scale of fees which was fixed by the Board of Architects and brought to them for approval and that in dealing with that scale of fees I referred also to an Architects (Amendment) Ordinance which we at that time proposed but which was withdrawn as the life of the Assembly was then extremely uncertain. In referring to these fees, I pointed out that the changes in the scale of fees were only one stage in a general reassessment.

    Since then, certain aspects arising from the operation of the scale of fees have called for study and have received study and I now move an Architects (Amendment) Bill which is significantly different from what we proposed in 1956.

    In clause 2 we seek to remove from the Board of Architects the power to fix a scale of fees and I think I had better explain the background to that a little because Members may not be fully in the picture. The argument which has been used to justify a scale of fees fixed under statutory powers is that the architects in Singapore are required to give a degree of supervision to building works which is not required in many other countries. If hon. Members have in their hands the 1956 scale of fees, they will note that it was then laid down that one-fifth of the total fees would be payable on the completion of the sketch plans; the balance up to two-thirds when the contracts have been let; and the remaining one-third would be paid by instalments as the architect from time to time certified progress to his client for payment to the contractors. This implies of course that two-thirds (or 5 per cent) of the fee is appropriate for designing a structure and that 2½ per cent is the appropriate fee for supervision.

Column: 2094

We are here concerned with the supervision aspect; that is the aspect on which the argument for statutory power to fix a scale is based.

    Supervision is defined in section 1 of the 1956 scale and was previously defined in the 1932 scale and it is linked with the local authority by-laws: No. 20 in the Rural Board, I think it is No. 41 in the Municipal by-laws and deriving from a section of the Municipal Ordinance. Briefly, the effect of this is that the person who is responsible as the architect must certify that the contractors have observed the by-laws during the building works.
